issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: This issue is undergoing QA.  See linked QA issue(s) for progress.
status.name: In QA

fields.description:
When putting an object to S3 the user can explicitly specify access permissions. When access permissions are specified the service should not add the x-amz-grant-full-control permission for object owner.

Currently we use the specified permissions but also add an extra x-amz-grant-full-control permission for object owner.
fields.summary: S3 put object always grants x-amz-grant-full-control for object owner

comments.body: [~sjones], [~swathi] what would be the best way to reproduce this issue?

[~mmunn1], I have not looked into fixing this issue so do not know if that is the right approach. In general, we should probably have a clear distinction between the cases where a default policy is being used and where a user specified policy is being processed. I'm not sure if there are any "required" permissions that should also be added for object or bucket access policies.

[~sjones] In your example on how to reproduce this issue the ACL  that is output from get-object-acl seems to be correct according to the Canned ACL definition at  http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/acl-overview.html#canned-acl

What am I missing here?  It seems that only log-delivery-write should not have owner = FULL_CONTROL
I am currently testing a fix but I am seeing a few s3 regression tests failing and will continue to investigate.
Looks good to me [~mmunn1], thanks!
[~sjones] Should I create a separate bug for this, put-object-acl? It is a separate code path.
[~mmunn1], feel free to open another ticket for put object acl if you prefer. We should fix it for 4.4.
[~sjones] I will file a new bug for the put-*-acl calls, the fact that it's both buckets and objects does simplify things.

[~mmunn1], I think further investigation is required to determine the correct fix for this issue (authorization changes may also be needed). The best approach may be to revert the changes in 4.4 and revisit this for 5.0 along with other changes (i.e. bucket policy)

[~sjones] I tend to agree we would have to change most of the N4j and nephoria bucket tests as well to handle these changes. Should I go ahead and revert the fix or do we want to discuss this at the bug scrub?
[~mmunn1], we should probably discuss at the bug scrub today.
Let's revert this for now.
Reverted fix in maint-4.4
[~mmunn1], I'm working on bucket policies for 5.0 ( EUCA-13105 ), any objection to my taking this issue to look at at the same time?
[~sjones] No feel free to take this one. Thanks!

Related n4j pull request:

  https://github.com/eucalyptus/n4j/pull/47

We no longer add the default owner full control permissions when creating or putting acls for objects and buckets. This change has no impact on the permissions granted to the resource owner.
Requires corresponding n4j test code change, tracked in EUCA-13269
